quest.name: The Bozja Incident
journal: The Ironworks engineer is confused as to why you are still here and not at the Doman Enclave.

You begin to strike up another conversation with Lilja who, perhaps fearing the ire of her superiors, quickly directs you to the Doman Enclave. Rather than engage her with more friendly banter, you set your sights on the enclave to meet with Cid.

You arrive at the Doman Enclave to find Cid preoccupied with the calm and quiet of the settlement, but his stern expression makes clear he understands why he has come. Though apprehensive of what awaits him at Gangos, Cid reaffirms his commitment to helping the Bozjan Resistance. Together you board the airship which bears the two of you to Gangos.

Together with Mikoto you delve into Cid's memories of Bozja Citadel. An arduous journey through his mind eventually leads you to a massive transmission tower, wherein you confront a manifestation of Cid's trauma in the form of Lord Varis.

The phantom of Cid's past is laid low, but something about this glimpse into the past still appears amiss. Realizing Lord Varis had no reason to be present at the citadel, he strains to remember who was the source of this anguished memory. In an instant his mind becomes clear, and the visage of Lord Varis is replaced by the man who shot him so many years ago─his own father, Midas nan Garlond. What's more, a closer inspection reveals he is in fact a thrall of the dreadwyrm Bahamut. With the mystery of Cid's past brought to light, you return to the waking world with the inscriptions of the blades of Gunnhildr, as well as an onerous truth.

Gerolt has begun work on reforging the blades of Gunnhildr, bringing the people of Bozja one step closer to reclaiming their homeland. There is much to do in preparation for their encounter with the Empire, and Marsak bids you speak with Gerolt to learn what part you yet have to play.
objectives: Ask after Cid at the Doman Enclave.

dialogue.name: GEROLT
dialogue.text: If it ain't about me forge, it'll have to wait, lasslad. I...I need to think.

dialogue.name: IRONWORKSCLERK
dialogue.text: The chief said he'd be meeting you at the Doman Enclave, didn't he? Well, best not keep him waiting.

dialogue.name: IRONWORKSCLERK
dialogue.text: As much as I enjoy your company, I understand duty calls. Hopefully we'll have the chance to talk another time.

dialogue.name: AIRSHIPGUIDE
dialogue.text: Master Garlond? Yes, I've seen him restlessly pacing about the enclave. If you wait here, I'm sure he'll come by before long.

dialogue.name: CID
dialogue.text: It's hard to believe this place was, until recently, occupied by the Garleans. Doma has a long way to go before it regains its former glory, but they're off to a good start.

dialogue.name: CID
dialogue.text: So I've heard. If the Bozjans wish to follow the Domans' lead, I plan to do what I can to help them.

dialogue.name: CID
dialogue.text: In fact, I've already spoken to Lord Hien and agreed to divert part of the Ironworks' resources to assist in Doma's reconstruction.

dialogue.name: CID
dialogue.text: The offer seemed to have taken him by surprise, but I assured him that in addition to the Ironworks' commitment to freedom through technology, I have my own reasons to reverse the destruction wrought by the Empire.

dialogue.name: CID
dialogue.text: While it's true that I eventually defected, I played no small part in the development of magitek now used by their military.

dialogue.name: CID
dialogue.text: <sigh> Sometimes it's the threads you can't see that have the strongest ties. Would that I could cut them.

dialogue.name: Q1
dialogue.text: What will you say?

dialogue.name: A1
dialogue.text: And how did Lord Hien take your response?

dialogue.name: A2
dialogue.text: The Empire's sins aren't yours to bear.

dialogue.name: CID
dialogue.text: Our talks were focused mainly on the reconstruction, as we thought it best to wait for your arrival to discuss how I might help the Bozjans.

dialogue.name: CID
dialogue.text: Even so, not a day goes by that I don't think about the part I played in the atrocities they committed.

dialogue.name: CID
dialogue.text: <sigh> If I could have made my father see reason, there would have been no Bozja incident.

dialogue.name: CID
dialogue.text: ...But I was powerless to stop him.

dialogue.name: CID
dialogue.text: Yes, you're right. There's a time for wallowing in self-pity and a time for action. I plan to do whatever I can for the Bozjan Resistance, but they're up against the IVth Legion...

dialogue.name: CID
dialogue.text: If they're to stand a chance, their allies here in the East won't be enough. They're going to need all the help they can muster.

dialogue.name: CID
dialogue.text: I'm not entirely sure what part I'll have to play in all this, and I doubt anything I do now will be enough to atone for my past mistakes.

dialogue.name: CID
dialogue.text: But if it means throwing a spanner in the Empire's works, then count me in.

dialogue.name: GEROLT
dialogue.text: He can fashion all manner o' magitek gadgets and whatnot, I'll give him that, but if it's a kettle yer after, that's where ol' Gerolt really shines.

dialogue.name: SYSTEM
dialogue.text: Upon speaking with Mikoto, several cutscenes will play in sequence.

dialogue.name: SYSTEM
dialogue.text: It is recommended that you set aside sufficient time to view these scenes in their entirety.

dialogue.name: SYSTEM
dialogue.text: You must be a Disciple of War or Magic of level 80 or above to proceed.

dialogue.name: Q1
dialogue.text: Proceed and speak with Mikoto?

dialogue.name: MIKOTO
dialogue.text: If you are ready, I would begin our exploration. Think back to your time at Bozja Citadel. You needn't focus on a specific memory, if that helps.

dialogue.name: CID
dialogue.text: All right. Just promise me you'll be careful in there.

dialogue.name: SOLUSZOSGALVUS
dialogue.text: (-Solus zos Galvus-)Know your place, whelp. The Meteor project cannot─will not─be stopped. Certainly not by the likes of you.

dialogue.name: CID
dialogue.text: No... No, this is wrong. Emperor Solus couldn't have been there.

dialogue.name: CID
dialogue.text: No, please! Lord Varis... Nooo!

dialogue.name: MIKOTO
dialogue.text: Cid! Cid, you mustn't forget─this is only a memory!

dialogue.name: VARIS
dialogue.text: Cid Garlond, bringer of ruin. Herald of ash. Your father must be proud.

dialogue.name: VARIS
dialogue.text: How does it feel to know such calamity follows in your wake? That your failings bring death to all you hold dear?

dialogue.name: VARIS
dialogue.text: And now you would set this filth against me. Very well...

dialogue.name: VARIS
dialogue.text: But one fate awaits those who oppose the will of the Empire.

dialogue.name: MIKOTO
dialogue.text: This trauma is too much─he's lost control!

dialogue.name: MIKOTO
dialogue.text: But this memory is false, Forename! Perhaps you can alter it with the Echo!

dialogue.name: Q1
dialogue.text: What will you do?

dialogue.name: A1
dialogue.text: Think of your truest friends.

dialogue.name: A2
dialogue.text: Think of your strongest allies.

dialogue.name: CID
dialogue.text: That was...always your greatest strength... Instilling in others the courage to rise up... The courage to fight for what's right.

dialogue.name: CID
dialogue.text: This...isn't right, either. Emperor...Lord Varis... He wasn't there. The Academy was given full charge of the project.

dialogue.name: MIKOTO
dialogue.text: Though these events are as you remember them, this is not the truth. Not entirely. Whoever this is, your mind has been trying to protect you from them.

dialogue.name: CID
dialogue.text: Well if it isn't Varis, then who in the hells is it? What could I possibly have to hide from myself?

dialogue.name: CID
dialogue.text: So it was you who pulled the trigger... Father.

dialogue.name: MIKOTO
dialogue.text: Cid, look! His eyes!

dialogue.name: CID
dialogue.text: No...it can't be.

dialogue.name: MIKOTO
dialogue.text: If contact with Dalamud was able to stir Bahamut to consciousness, it stands to reason the dreadwyrm discovered a way to link to the tower and thereby enslave your father.

dialogue.name: MIKOTO
dialogue.text: In which case, there was nothing that could be done for him. There is no arguing or reasoning with such individuals. There is only the will of the primal.

dialogue.name: MIKOTO
dialogue.text: And if Bahamut was controlling your father at the time of the accident...

dialogue.name: CID
dialogue.text: Then in all likelihood, it wasn't an accident.

dialogue.name: CID
dialogue.text: And so the truth finally comes to light.

dialogue.name: CID
dialogue.text: Bahamut's thrall, and no one was the wiser. Not even your own son...

dialogue.name: GEROLT
dialogue.text: Ye crazy bastards did it! Once Mikoto's described the inscriptions to me, I'll have those weapons forged in no time!

dialogue.name: BAISHAEN
dialogue.text: On behalf of the Bozjan Resistance, you have my deepest thanks.

dialogue.name: CID
dialogue.text: I'm just glad I could help.

dialogue.name: BAISHAEN
dialogue.text: Ever since that fateful day, the truth of what befell our loved ones had eluded us.

dialogue.name: BAISHAEN
dialogue.text: I held the Empire and your father responsible for their part in the tragedy, and for many years, that hatred was all that kept me going.

dialogue.name: BAISHAEN
dialogue.text: Indeed, I was blinded by that hatred. So much so that even you appeared to me as an enemy. I could not see the blood, sweat, and tears you have poured into bettering the lives of those seeking freedom from the Empire.

dialogue.name: BAISHAEN
dialogue.text: I could see only a Garlean. And for that, I am sorry.

dialogue.name: BAISHAEN
dialogue.text: If you can forgive me, let us be allies, united against a common foe.

dialogue.name: CID
dialogue.text: Come now, I'm the one who should apologize to you. After all my father and the Empire did, even if not all of their own volition, their crimes will never be forgotten.

dialogue.name: CID
dialogue.text: I'd hazard even victory over the Empire won't be enough to ease such pain. And even now that I know the truth behind the Bozja incident, all it's done is make me question the choices that led me here to this moment.

dialogue.name: CID
dialogue.text: But regardless of the past, we have to keep pressing forward, one step at a time. For freedom.

dialogue.name: BAISHAEN
dialogue.text: Just as the heroes of eld would have done. We Bozjans grew up on such tales, of peerless warriors pure of heart and unwavering in their conviction. Yet here we are, so full of doubt and uncertainty. Will we ever earn our place in the pages of history?

dialogue.name: CID
dialogue.text: Cheer up, Bajsaljen. If we live long enough, perhaps we'll be the ones to pen them.

dialogue.name: CID
dialogue.text: You say the crystal focus is no longer responsive?

dialogue.name: MIKOTO
dialogue.text: It would appear what stores of aether resided within it have been depleted. I did not expect our exploration of your mind to be such a taxing endeavor.

dialogue.name: MIKOTO
dialogue.text: Once I identify its aetheric affinity, and a power source with a compliant energy frequency, I am confident its reserves can be replenished.

dialogue.name: CID
dialogue.text: I thought perhaps the Alliance could use it to extract information from some of their less cooperative Garlean captives, but nothing's ever that easy, is it?

dialogue.name: CID
dialogue.text: I'm afraid aetherology is beyond the scope of my expertise, so I'll leave the rest to you. If you need anything, don't hesitate to call for me.

dialogue.name: MIKOTO
dialogue.text: Thank you for all your help, Master Cid.

dialogue.name: CID
dialogue.text: Well, I'd better head back. I've a mountain of work waiting for me.

dialogue.name: MIKOTO
dialogue.text: Er, before you go...

dialogue.name: MIKOTO
dialogue.text: If you ever feel lost, you...you can always talk to me...

dialogue.name: CID
dialogue.text: Of course. If I run into any aether-related problems, you'll be the first to know.

dialogue.name: MIKOTO
dialogue.text: Right! I, er... I really must get to work on the crystal focus!

dialogue.name: GEROLT
dialogue.text: I told him I didn't need no assistant, but Marsak insisted. His name is, uh... Er... Well, he's standin' right there. Ask him yerself.

dialogue.name: ZLATAN
dialogue.text: Forename Surname? I am Zlatan. It's an honor to meet you. I've not much experience with the forge, but it is my hope that I might improve working under Master Gerolt.

dialogue.name: ZLATAN
dialogue.text: The first step in my training appears to be getting him to remember my name...

dialogue.name: WANDERINGWRITER
dialogue.text: Forename! My, my, that I should find you here of all places. Though I suppose that's only right, considering I followed you. My well of inspiration has run dry, you see, and it is my hope that a change of scenery might offer the impetus my work requires.

dialogue.name: WANDERINGWRITER
dialogue.text: And time and again you have proven a knack for finding fascinating locales, with equally fascinating stories unfolding soon thereafter.

dialogue.name: WANDERINGWRITER
dialogue.text: When such a tantalizing tale finally does unfold, I should very much like to hear it.

dialogue.name: MARSHAK
dialogue.text: Everything is at last in place to begin work on the weapons of Queen Gunnhildr's guard. Master Gerolt will be able to apprise you of any further progress in their forging.

dialogue.name: MARSHAK
dialogue.text: In the meantime, we will begin preparations for battle. I look forward to seeing you on the front lines.

dialogue.name: SYSTEM
dialogue.text: Attuning to all Aethernet shards in the Doman Enclave will now unlock Gangos as an Aethernet destination.

dialogue.name: SYSTEM
dialogue.text: Meanwhile, at Valnain in Dalmasca...

dialogue.name: MENENIUS
dialogue.text: Our spies at the Gangos encampment have confirmed work on the blades of Gunnhildr is underway.

dialogue.name: GABRANTH
dialogue.text: Hmph. They are welcome to them. Who has need of such trinkets when the lady of blades will soon be in play?

dialogue.name: GABRANTH
dialogue.text: We will proceed as planned. When their forces reach Bozja, you know what must be done.

dialogue.name: MENENIUS
dialogue.text: Understood.

dialogue.name: GABRANTH
dialogue.text: The Empire is fated to fall. But in its place a new nation shall rise, grander and mightier than anything the Garleans could ever have dreamed.

dialogue.name: GABRANTH
dialogue.text: And it shall be made possible by the very power they abhor.

dialogue.name: BAISHAEN
dialogue.text: I do not imagine he sympathizes with our plight, but from what I gather, he has no love for the Empire, either. If that will suffice in persuading him to aid us, then so be it.

dialogue.name: BAISHAEN
dialogue.text: I hear there are engineers stationed at Rhalgr's Reach. Perhaps you can begin your search for Garlond there.

dialogue.name: BAISHAEN
dialogue.text: Unless...there is something else you wish to discuss?

dialogue.name: BAISHAEN
dialogue.text: I would be lying if I said I understand what it is you must do, but I will pray for your safety all the same.

dialogue.name: BAISHAEN
dialogue.text: Is there aught you wish to discuss before you begin?

dialogue.name: BAISHAEN
dialogue.text: On behalf of the Resistance, I thank you again for lending your strength to our cause. Reforging the blades of Gunnhildr is certain to stir the fire in our men's hearts.

dialogue.name: BAISHAEN
dialogue.text: When the battle begins in earnest, I should hope we can count on your continued assistance.

dialogue.name: BAISHAEN
dialogue.text: Now then, is there aught you wish to discuss?

dialogue.name: Q10
dialogue.text: What will you say?

dialogue.name: A10
dialogue.text: Tell me about Bozja and the Resistance.

dialogue.name: A10
dialogue.text: Tell me about Gangos.

dialogue.name: A10
dialogue.text: Tell me about the Bozja incident.

dialogue.name: A10
dialogue.text: Tell me about yourself.

dialogue.name: A10
dialogue.text: Nothing.

dialogue.name: BAISHAEN
dialogue.text: Our home rests in the southern reaches of Ilsabard, to the west of Dalmasca.

dialogue.name: BAISHAEN
dialogue.text: Our earliest records─or at least those we have been able to recover─suggest Bozja was founded at some point during the Third Astral Era. The Allagan Empire had reached the height of its power, and several tribes of the Hrothgar came here seeking refuge from their supremacy.

dialogue.name: BAISHAEN
dialogue.text: It was Queen Gunnhildr who would keep the Allagans at bay. Her radiance would light our path to prosperity, and by her grace was the nation of Bozja founded.

dialogue.name: BAISHAEN
dialogue.text: Alas, the Fourth Umbral Calamity would see the end of her kingdom. But those who survived slowly rebuilt, and Bozja was reborn as a city-state that would coexist with neighboring nations for centuries to come.

dialogue.name: BAISHAEN
dialogue.text: The Garlean Empire's rise to power changed everything. None could oppose the sheer strength and versatility of their military.

dialogue.name: BAISHAEN
dialogue.text: Their campaign began some fifty years ago, and now an entire generation of our people has been raised knowing only oppression. But now they would know freedom.

dialogue.name: BAISHAEN
dialogue.text: When word reached us that Ala Mhigo and Doma had risen up to defy the Empire, we seized the opportunity to flee and form pockets of resistance.

dialogue.name: BAISHAEN
dialogue.text: With Lord Hien's assistance, the several groups that had formed were merged into a single, cohesive force, and I was chosen as its leader.

dialogue.name: BAISHAEN
dialogue.text: If the IVth Imperial Legion is able to consolidate its forces in Bozja, however, our efforts will be for naught. We have to strike back, and soon.

dialogue.name: BAISHAEN
dialogue.text: For the present, this is our base of operations, to the southeast of what remains of Bozja Citadel. When the fighting begins, we will hold the line here.

dialogue.name: BAISHAEN
dialogue.text: For a blessing, the surrounding wetlands and the fog that persists year-round have served to conceal our operation. That is not to say, of course, we have not taken additional measures to remain hidden.

dialogue.name: BAISHAEN
dialogue.text: In the unlikely event that their scouts should approach the perimeter, our mages have cast a cloaking spell around the area to keep us from sight.

dialogue.name: BAISHAEN
dialogue.text: Havens such as this are plentiful along the southern coast of Ilsabard. Our facilities are rather modest, I confess, but I would like to think we have made great strides in providing for our soldiers here.

dialogue.name: BAISHAEN
dialogue.text: Thanks to the generosity of our allies here in the East, as well as the Eorzean Alliance, we do not want for provisions or arms. All that remains is to secure the blades of Gunnhildr.

dialogue.name: BAISHAEN
dialogue.text: It was roughly twenty years ago, if I'm not mistaken. The Empire, fearful of the threat posed by primals and the tribes who summoned them, devised a plan to wipe them out.

dialogue.name: BAISHAEN
dialogue.text: The Meteor project. Through the use of magitek, they intended to recreate ancient sorcery capable of calling down meteors.

dialogue.name: BAISHAEN
dialogue.text: At the helm of the project was their chief engineer, Midas nan Garlond. In time, every last one of their research facilities was involved in its development.

dialogue.name: BAISHAEN
dialogue.text: The project would take a perilous turn when it was discovered that the lesser moon Dalamud was, in fact, a satellite of Allagan design. They were determined to make it part of their plans.

dialogue.name: BAISHAEN
dialogue.text: And so they erected a colossal transmission tower, designed to control Dalamud. Its first test would also prove to be its last...

dialogue.name: BAISHAEN
dialogue.text: For lack of eyewitnesses, what happened next is difficult to describe. It is often described as an explosion, but the ruins showed no signs of gunpowder or magic. We only know that a terrible light shone from the heavens that night.

dialogue.name: BAISHAEN
dialogue.text: In an instant, the citadel was gone. Its citizens and soldiers...my family...

dialogue.name: BAISHAEN
dialogue.text: No one is certain why Dalamud responded with such destructive force, but all work on the Meteor project was halted immediately.

dialogue.name: BAISHAEN
dialogue.text: Five years later, however, Nael van Darnus set the wheels of the project back into motion. His devotion was rewarded with the coming of the Seventh Umbral Calamity.

dialogue.name: BAISHAEN
dialogue.text: The world has already paid too great a cost for the Garleans' ambition... They must be stopped.

dialogue.name: BAISHAEN
dialogue.text: I was born in Bozja, though I have never known a life free from the Empire's rule.

dialogue.name: BAISHAEN
dialogue.text: Following in my late father's footsteps, I studied to become a doctor. Much to my surprise, and dismay, my academic accomplishments did not go unnoticed. I was taken to the capital, where I received a formal education in medicinal sciences. Deployment as a medic in their military soon followed.

dialogue.name: BAISHAEN
dialogue.text: My service was ultimately rewarded with citizenship, after which I met my wife, and we started a family together. If their goal was for me to grow content and complacent, it failed, for not a day went by that I did not think about the liberation of my homeland.

dialogue.name: BAISHAEN
dialogue.text: But I would need to bide my time a while longer, for I was assigned to the IVth Imperial Legion. There was an uprising in Nagxia, and it fell to us to quell their insurrection. It was not until after our mission was complete that I learned of what happened to Bozja. To my family...

dialogue.name: BAISHAEN
dialogue.text: We returned as fast as we were able, but there was nothing left of the citadel.

dialogue.name: BAISHAEN
dialogue.text: I was ordered to return to the capital, but I had to find my wife and children. I covered every ilm of that barren wasteland...and nothing.

dialogue.name: BAISHAEN
dialogue.text: Chains and a prison cell greeted me back in Garlemald, but in spite of my confinement, whispers of what happened in Bozja eventually reached me. Of their failed experiments to control Dalamud.

dialogue.name: BAISHAEN
dialogue.text: Stripped of my citizenship, I expected to remain under lock and key until the end of my days. Fortunately for me, they had need of more medics for their next campaign.

dialogue.name: BAISHAEN
dialogue.text: But I would never reach the battlefield, for I escaped with a number of other soldiers to join the Resistance.

dialogue.name: BAISHAEN
dialogue.text: Many years of service to the Resistance then molded me into the man who now stands before you. And I will continue to serve for as long as it takes to see our homeland safe from the Empire.

dialogue.name: MARSHAK
dialogue.text: That you should know Cid Garlond is hardly surprising. I only hope he is not so engrossed in his work that he cannot find time to assist us.

dialogue.name: MARSHAK
dialogue.text: I will not keep you. Unless, of course, there is something you wish to ask me?

dialogue.name: MARSHAK
dialogue.text: We are quite fortunate that Mikoto was available to assist us. Never did I think she would devise such a unique solution to our problem.

dialogue.name: MARSHAK
dialogue.text: I'm sure the two of you have much to discuss, so I will leave you to your work. Unless there is something else you wish to ask me?

dialogue.name: Q20
dialogue.text: What will you say?

dialogue.name: A20
dialogue.text: Tell me about the IVth Imperial Legion.

dialogue.name: A20
dialogue.text: Tell me about Legatus Noah van Gabranth.

dialogue.name: A20
dialogue.text: Tell me about Castrum Lacus Litore.

dialogue.name: A20
dialogue.text: Tell me about yourself.

dialogue.name: A20
dialogue.text: Nothing.

dialogue.name: MARSHAK
dialogue.text: The initial invasion of Bozja was led by Basch van Gabranth. There would be a change of commander not long after, however.

dialogue.name: MARSHAK
dialogue.text: Thirty years ago, during the invasion of Dalmasca, his health took an unexpected turn for the worse, and his son, Noah van Gabranth, oversaw the conquest to its completion. He was a mere twenty years old when he assumed full command.

dialogue.name: MARSHAK
dialogue.text: The IVth Imperial Legion itself is rather unique compared to most, for the bulk of their forces are not native Garleans, their present leader included.

dialogue.name: MARSHAK
dialogue.text: Both Noah and his father were quite quick to bend the knee to Emperor Solus, from what I have been told. Perhaps it was that ardent loyalty that helped them rise to such prominence.

dialogue.name: MARSHAK
dialogue.text: But not all were such fervent followers of the Empire. Quite the contrary, I would hazard the greater part of their soldiers were like us, seeing little recourse but to serve lest they be put to the sword.

dialogue.name: MARSHAK
dialogue.text: Though I suppose the unwavering loyalty of the IVth Imperial Legion is what serves to set it apart from the rest. Or to be more precise, its loyalty to Noah van Gabranth.

dialogue.name: MARSHAK
dialogue.text: What's more, you will come to find they are not wont to rely on magitek armaments like most imperial soldiers.

dialogue.name: MARSHAK
dialogue.text: Indeed, they seem to prefer fighting the old-fashioned way, employing arcane magicks, techniques akin to summoning, and all manner of feral beasts rather than depending on heavy artillery.

dialogue.name: MARSHAK
dialogue.text: Though if recent reports are to be believed, these will be the least of our concerns. The battalions en route to Bozja are said to be led by Lyon sas Helsos.

dialogue.name: MARSHAK
dialogue.text: He is a strategist whose cunning is matched only by his renown as a tamer of beasts, and it is rumored that he alone is worth more than a thousand rank-and-file troops. One might say he has history with the Resistance.

dialogue.name: MARSHAK
dialogue.text: Ah yes, the leader of the IVth Imperial Legion, one of the youngest to ever take such a position. His father, Basch van Gabranth, served as legatus before him, claiming many a victory in the name of the Empire.

dialogue.name: MARSHAK
dialogue.text: Basch was a knight of the Republic of Landis, which, like so many other nations, was fast to fall at the hands of the Empire. Rather than die with dignity, he was quite quick to bend the knee to their conquerors, ingratiating himself with the Emperor and earning his place as a legatus.

dialogue.name: MARSHAK
dialogue.text: This was quite a feat, given that he was not of Garlean blood. One can but imagine the lengths to which he went to earn their trust, but it is clear he labored hard to keep it.

dialogue.name: MARSHAK
dialogue.text: His health took an unexpected turn for the worse during the invasion of Dalmasca, which afforded Noah the opportunity he needed to rise to prominence. And it was under Noah's leadership that Rabanastre would fall.

dialogue.name: MARSHAK
dialogue.text: Then, when his father passed two years later, he was named the next legatus of the IVth Imperial Legion.

dialogue.name: MARSHAK
dialogue.text: Many believe it was the conquest of Dalmasca that earned him the position, but some argue he was appointed on the recommendation of the Emperor, perhaps in recognition of his father's service to the Empire.

dialogue.name: MARSHAK
dialogue.text: Regardless of the reason, Noah would continue in his father's footsteps. The IVth Imperial Legion would continue to be comprised primarily of foreign soldiers, and their loyalty to the newly appointed legatus was unfaltering.

dialogue.name: MARSHAK
dialogue.text: One might expect such a legion to remain within the Emperor's good graces, but it would not be so when Varis took the throne. For several years he appointed them to the quelling of uprisings in remote provinces, as if to keep them at arm's length.

dialogue.name: MARSHAK
dialogue.text: Perhaps he suspected an ulterior motive to the Gabranths seeking to gain such fervent adoration from the IVth Imperial Legion. I have no proof, of course, but one cannot help but wonder...

dialogue.name: MARSHAK
dialogue.text: It was once known as Alermuc Fortress, erected in the hopes of deterring the Garleans. After the Bozja incident, it would be rebuilt and given a new name─Castrum Lacus Litore.

dialogue.name: MARSHAK
dialogue.text: Its position to the north of Bozja will make it a critical strategic point in the battles to come. If we are to have any hope of reclaiming Bozja, we must first gain control of the castrum.

dialogue.name: MARSHAK
dialogue.text: The location was originally chosen for its natural defenses. Being surrounded on all sides by steep cliffs made Alermuc Fortress all but impregnable. Assuming, of course, one had the wherewithal to defend it.

dialogue.name: MARSHAK
dialogue.text: When the Garleans came, their magitek weaponry was unlike anything we had ever seen. A great many lives were lost in our struggle to hold the fortress, and in the end we were simply outmatched.

dialogue.name: MARSHAK
dialogue.text: At present, the castrum is held by Legatus Gabranth's second-in-command, Menenius rem Lanatus. An interesting choice, to say the least.

dialogue.name: MARSHAK
dialogue.text: Lanatus is a well-known family with a long and august lineage. That is, until they incurred the ire of the Emperor, tarnishing their name and robbing them of their position in Garlean society.

dialogue.name: MARSHAK
dialogue.text: And yet Basch van Gabranth would choose members of their family to serve under him. Mayhap he sensed their desperation to redeem their honor. If that is the case, the road to redemption is long indeed, for two generations of Lanatus have served under the Gabranths.

dialogue.name: MARSHAK
dialogue.text: Imagine the recognition they would receive for thwarting our attempts to take the fortress. You can be sure he will do all in his power to stop us.

dialogue.name: MARSHAK
dialogue.text: I serve primarily as liaison 'twixt the Bozjan Resistance and our allies. I'll not deny there is still much for me to learn, but I will do everything within my power to see Bozja free of the Empire. If that should mean my life, then so be it.

dialogue.name: MARSHAK
dialogue.text: You...wish to know of my past? It is no different than most, I would imagine─conscription by the Empire, which is the only reason I was not present in the citadel to die alongside my kin in the Bozja incident.

dialogue.name: MARSHAK
dialogue.text: Some would call it a massacre planned by the Empire, but I am not ready to believe they would willingly kill so many of their own soldiers and engineers.

dialogue.name: MARSHAK
dialogue.text: Having been raised under the Garlean doctrine, I realize that not all of them are the bloodthirsty monsters many of us would paint them to be. Though the Empire would seek to oppress us, I do not share the same animosity towards its citizens as my Resistance comrades.

dialogue.name: MARSHAK
dialogue.text: But these are musings better left between the two of us, yes? I would not have the others think me a coward or a traitor to our cause.

dialogue.name: MEESIYA
dialogue.text: The son of Midas nan Garlond. An imperial deserter... My, what curious company we keep.

dialogue.name: MEESIYA
dialogue.text: Ahem. Forgive me. Is there aught you need?

dialogue.name: MEESIYA
dialogue.text: Would that I could do more to assist you and Mikoto, but I know when I am out of my depth.

dialogue.name: MEESIYA
dialogue.text: If there is aught else I can do to assist, you need only ask.

dialogue.name: MEESIYA
dialogue.text: Our people yet want for the courage to fight, and I am confident the blades of Gunnhildr will afford them just that.

dialogue.name: MEESIYA
dialogue.text: There is still much we must do to prepare, but if there is aught else you wish to discuss...?

dialogue.name: Q30
dialogue.text: What will you say?

dialogue.name: A30
dialogue.text: Tell me about Queen Gunnhildr.

dialogue.name: A30
dialogue.text: Tell me about Gunnhildr's Blades.

dialogue.name: A30
dialogue.text: Tell me about the weapons you plan to forge.

dialogue.name: A30
dialogue.text: Tell me about yourself.

dialogue.name: A30
dialogue.text: Nothing.

dialogue.name: MEESIYA
dialogue.text: During the Third Astral Era, Queen Gunnhildr united the fragmented tribes of the Hrothgar to rise up and drove off the Allagans, eventually going on to found the nation of Bozja.

dialogue.name: MEESIYA
dialogue.text: It should be noted that Gunnhildr was not her name, but rather a title bestowed to the current monarch of any given age. The common thread connecting all rulers of Bozja is their ability to read the stars. There were others who shared in this ability, but they were said to be the greatest seers of their respective ages.

dialogue.name: MEESIYA
dialogue.text: They were also said to be great warriors. When doing battle with the Allagans or any other would-be invaders, the queen could always be found commanding from the front lines.

dialogue.name: MEESIYA
dialogue.text: Alas, Bozja would fall in the wake of the Fourth Umbral Calamity. By some miracle, some few survived and were able to build what we knew as the city-state of Bozja.

dialogue.name: MEESIYA
dialogue.text: They were the elite guard of the queen, masters of myriad arms and magicks, said to be the greatest warriors of their age.

dialogue.name: MEESIYA
dialogue.text: Their combat prowess was matched only by their devotion to Queen Gunnhildr. They would not hesitate to give their lives in her service. And, should one of these warriors fall in battle, their holy blade would be passed on to a suitable successor.

dialogue.name: MEESIYA
dialogue.text: Over time, their title as Gunnhildr's Blades would become synonymous with the gunblade, which gained great renown during the war against the Allagans.

dialogue.name: MEESIYA
dialogue.text: There is not a Bozjan alive who does not know the tales of their heroism. I have no doubt reforging these weapons will lend us both the strength and resolve we need to succeed.

dialogue.name: MEESIYA
dialogue.text: With Master Gerolt's help, we have nearly all that is required to reforge the weapons of Queen Gunnhildr's guard.

dialogue.name: MEESIYA
dialogue.text: While it is true the legends of their might are duly inspiring, to simply call them the blades of Gunnhildr would do little to differentiate these new armaments from the weapons of eld. After all, we do not wish to give the impression that the originals have been recovered.

dialogue.name: MEESIYA
dialogue.text: After much thought, Master Gerolt offered a simple and surprisingly satisfactory suggestion of “Resistance weapons.”

dialogue.name: MEESIYA
dialogue.text: He also went on to make a rather curious remark about the steps to be taken in their forging: that these weapons can be enhanced further in accordance with the enemies one faces.

dialogue.name: MEESIYA
dialogue.text: By the sounds of it, these weapons are never truly complete until their purpose is fulfilled.

dialogue.name: MEESIYA
dialogue.text: It has been two years since I joined the Resistance. Before then I lived as all Bozjans did─under the harsh rule of the Empire.

dialogue.name: MEESIYA
dialogue.text: It is the only life I have ever known, though my parents often spoke to me of what they remembered from the days of Bozja's independence.

dialogue.name: MEESIYA
dialogue.text: Though it was under the auspices of our Garlean oppressors, I was educated in prehistoric archaeology.

dialogue.name: MEESIYA
dialogue.text: While I am thankful for the opportunities afforded me, I could not turn a blind eye to the suffering of my people. And so I left to join the Resistance.

dialogue.name: MEESIYA
dialogue.text: It was I who proposed to reforge the fabled weapons of Queen Gunnhildr's guard, and Bajsaljen has chosen to place his faith in my plan. I take heart in knowing all I learned from the Empire will be put to good use.

dialogue.name: MIKOTO
dialogue.text: Our exploration of Master Gerolt's memories was a success. Largely in part to his trust in you, I suspect.

dialogue.name: MIKOTO
dialogue.text: How fortunate for us that you should be a good acquaintance of Cid's. I'm sure there is much you must do to prepare, so I will not keep you.

dialogue.name: MIKOTO
dialogue.text: ...Was there something else?

dialogue.name: MIKOTO
dialogue.text: I am afraid the crystal focus has fallen dormant.

dialogue.name: MIKOTO
dialogue.text: It will take time, but I am confident its reserves of energy can be replenished.

dialogue.name: MIKOTO
dialogue.text: You will be the first to know when the crystal focus is ready.

dialogue.name: MIKOTO
dialogue.text: If there is nothing else, I will leave you to your duties.

dialogue.name: Q40
dialogue.text: What will you say?

dialogue.name: A40
dialogue.text: Tell me about the seers.

dialogue.name: A40
dialogue.text: Tell me about the crystal focus.

dialogue.name: A40
dialogue.text: Tell me about memory exploration.

dialogue.name: A40
dialogue.text: Tell me about your gift.

dialogue.name: A40
dialogue.text: Tell me about yourself.

dialogue.name: A40
dialogue.text: Nothing.

dialogue.name: MIKOTO
dialogue.text: Scant though they are, the records we have uncovered thus far suggest the practices of seers date back as far as the Fourth Astral Era.

dialogue.name: MIKOTO
dialogue.text: The region was plagued with all manner of natural disasters in those days, inciting great unrest not only amongst the Bozjans, but neighboring nations as well.

dialogue.name: MIKOTO
dialogue.text: It was during these tumultuous times seers first appeared. In fact, I have reason to believe they possessed the Echo.

dialogue.name: MIKOTO
dialogue.text: Using a crystal focus, they were able to delve into the minds of the downcast and the heartsick, seeking out their darkest memories and altering them to ease the peoples' burdens.

dialogue.name: MIKOTO
dialogue.text: Perhaps they saw the altering of minds as a necessity for their survival, but we must consider the ethical implications of such methods in this day and age. I have no doubt my betters in Sharlayan would consider it to be reprehensible.

dialogue.name: MIKOTO
dialogue.text: My initial analysis of the crystals suggests they are man-made. Nothing in my data can prove the materials are unique to this region, which leads me to believe the Bozjans─or rather, the seers─created them.

dialogue.name: MIKOTO
dialogue.text: However, given the intricate lattices found in these crystals, it seems highly improbable that the Bozjans could have produced them, considering the methods available to them in the Fourth Astral Era.

dialogue.name: MIKOTO
dialogue.text: In fact, on closer inspection, it became clear that its structure is quite similar to that found in Allagan constructs.

dialogue.name: MIKOTO
dialogue.text: Which then begs the question: who were the seers, and whence did they come? This is but a working theory, but I suspect their roots can be traced back to the Allagans themselves─perhaps survivors of the Fourth Umbral Calamity who wished to atone for the sins of their forebears.

dialogue.name: MIKOTO
dialogue.text: They came to these lands seeking a means to help the Bozjans, and in doing so created these crystal foci.

dialogue.name: MIKOTO
dialogue.text: ...Ahem. As I said, 'tis but a working theory. Though I understand if it sounds more like a flight of fancy.

dialogue.name: MIKOTO
dialogue.text: Perhaps I should start with a simple explanation, as I did before. Let us consider the composition of a person's aether, shall we? There is corporeal aether of the flesh, incorporeal aether of the soul, and the aetherial residue of an individual's memories.

dialogue.name: MIKOTO
dialogue.text: Were one to be possessed of only corporeal aether, they would be but a walking corpse. Conversely, entities comprised of only incorporeal aether are referred to in layman's terms as ghosts. Of course, a ghost that possesses residual memories could likely recall its past and retain self-awareness.

dialogue.name: MIKOTO
dialogue.text: Using a crystal focus, we can isolate the aetherial signature of memories, much in the same way the seers did. We can then delve into and explore specific memories conjured by the subject.

dialogue.name: MIKOTO
dialogue.text: We must be careful of what we observe, however, for while the information stored in a person's memories can be quite comprehensive, it is not always true to fact. They can be distorted due to the passage of time, or even when first committed to the mind as a result of personal bias.

dialogue.name: MIKOTO
dialogue.text: That is why it is important to mark the distinction between explicit and implicit memories.

dialogue.name: MIKOTO
dialogue.text: Explicit memories are those consciously stored and recalled, while implicit memories are more passively accumulated by our subconscious.

dialogue.name: MIKOTO
dialogue.text: When meeting someone for the first time, their appearance will be kept as part of our explicit memory, though this may fade with the passing of time. Should a great deal of time pass without meeting, however, such recollection can prove difficult.

dialogue.name: MIKOTO
dialogue.text: Yet in that moment, your mind also takes record of everything experienced by your sensory nervous system.

dialogue.name: MIKOTO
dialogue.text: Unfortunately, information called from explicit memory is quite sensitive to misrepresentations of events. After all, if an individual is actively choosing to recall an event, who is to say they will not make alterations to better suit their liking?

dialogue.name: MIKOTO
dialogue.text: That is why we seek information from implicit memory, which is more likely to be preserved free of the bias of an individual's worldview.

dialogue.name: MIKOTO
dialogue.text: The Echo can manifest itself in myriad ways dependent on the individual. I was gifted with the ability to peer into the future.

dialogue.name: MIKOTO
dialogue.text: It is a power much like prophetic dreams and divinations, and yet quite different, for such visions only tell of the future's potential.

dialogue.name: MIKOTO
dialogue.text: The Echo does not show me what may happen, but what will happen.

dialogue.name: MIKOTO
dialogue.text: Scholars speculate Mezaya Thousand Eyes too shared this gift, hence the alarming accuracy of the passages writ in her Divine Chronicles.

dialogue.name: MIKOTO
dialogue.text: These visions are a decidedly rare occurrence, usually containing some crucial insight into matters presently unfolding before me. For better or worse, I have never had visions of an impending threat on my life or those around me.

dialogue.name: MIKOTO
dialogue.text: Not that I would want to see such things, of course. Could you imagine, knowing of certain doom that cannot be avoided?

dialogue.name: MIKOTO
dialogue.text: I once spoke of my visions to an acquaintance─a relatively harmless glimpse of the future─and it resulted in a terrible argument. I fear I could not bear the weight of grimmer tidings...

dialogue.name: MIKOTO
dialogue.text: But that is neither here nor there. My gift is but a trivial thing. Nothing you should think to rely upon.

dialogue.name: MIKOTO
dialogue.text: About me!? Oh, there really isn't much to tell, I assure you!

dialogue.name: MIKOTO
dialogue.text: Well, if you must know... Due to advanced placement I found myself attending the Studium much earlier than most. My research in the field of aetherology would eventually earn me the title of Archon. When I am not conducting research in the field, I conduct lectures at the Studium.

dialogue.name: MIKOTO
dialogue.text: Moenbryda is, er...was...my mentor. I would not be the scholar I am today if not for her. I have fond memories of the many nights we toiled together working on her original plans for the aetheric siphon. She was like a sister to me.

dialogue.name: MIKOTO
dialogue.text: Speaking of which, I do have a sister, actually. An identical twin, in fact. Though we have not spoken since she too was named an Archon.

dialogue.name: MIKOTO
dialogue.text: She was my better in all aspects of academia, but she often disagreed with the views of the Forum. I can but assume that is why she took her leave of the Studium.

dialogue.name: MIKOTO
dialogue.text: She was always so strong-willed and quite critical of those around her. Sadly, we never got along very well growing up. I often wonder if that is why Moenbryda was so quick to take me under her wing.

dialogue.name: MIKOTO
dialogue.text: I still see her, in my dreams. Always offering a warm smile and words of encouragement.

dialogue.name: MIKOTO
dialogue.text: If we were to use the crystal focus, perhaps there would be a way to speak with her again. A tempting prospect, but in the end, I know it would not truly be her...
